values:
Walter drove back into town in the early morning/late night and went directly to his room. He was exhausted. There was something about traveling over six decades that was rather draining at times. But he'd had a bloody fine time, and he was back. Had it been two weeks? It was a pity he'd left without informing anyone, but sometimes, there just wasn't time to do anything but grab Pup and get in the car, luggage and phone calls be damned. 

So. The door was open and he was sprawled on his bed alternately dozing and playing with Pup. More dozing than playing. 

<small>[ooc: Door's open. Walter's missed everything.]

So, traveling with someone from old money (quite literally) had some real advantages. One of them was the private jet Walter was half-dozing on, Vlad nearby. "Catching up on his Romanian studies" involved a weekend of total immersion, by Vlad's suggestion, and it was difficult to turn it down. So much so, that he'd just not. Thus, the jet, the dozing, and the promise of jet lag. [ooc: NFB for distance, please handwave voicemails from Walter mentioning he'd be out of town for the weekend. NWS now. Forewarned is four-armed.]

After a day spent in New Orleans, Walter had contact lenses again, a few new books on current technology and weapons, a fantastic take-out dinner, and a good mood. 

He steered his car down the road away from the ferry dock and squinted when some exceptionally bright oncoming lights disrupted his vision. He slowed down and steered a bit to the side of the road to try to compensate for the vision problems. 

<small>[ooc: For the guest hero.]

Walter decided it was politic not to go out among his fellow students too much, since he wasn't particularly broken up about Thelma's death, but many people were. 

His door stood open and Pup would occasionally trot out into the hallway to see if there <s>were any invaders to maim, torture, and destroy</s> any new people to play with. <s>Or squirrels to impale! Yes!</s> 

Walter sat with his new <s>handwavily purchased</s> laptop and hunted the internet for unusual things to do with wine. Don't ask. He won't tell. 

<small>[ooc: Post, and door, are open.]

Walter had his rubbers, he had a backpack with a packed lunch that should manage to feed both himself and Nadia, and he had a book on plants and animals of Louisiana that he'd managed to get his hands on over the weekend. 

At the very least it would give them elimination comparisons while they hunted for a triffid. 

Whatever that was. 

Now all he needed was Nadia.

After the fun of the brawl in class, Walter went back to his room to collect Pup and bring him along to visit Vlad while he told him about Arthur. 

Pup wagged more and more frantically the closer they got to Blenner's home until he was practically vibrating like a tuning fork by the time they made it upstairs and to the door to knock. 

<small>[ooc: NFB and backdated]

Walter had offered Nadia dinner and dinner he had prepared. He decided it didn't really matter what he cooked as long as there was plenty of hot sauce to go with it, so he had lamb and rice stuffed tomatoes and peppers and a big bottle of hot sauce. 

He'd given Pup a quiet talking to about being a good boy, and was just waiting for his dinner guest. 

<small>[ooc: for Nadia]

Not sleeping was getting old. It was getting very old. Walter had snagged a couple of catnaps since Monday, but that was it. He'd been glad of the distraction that had come from doing things like being "it" in Nadia's running game in SERF, but when the distractions were gone, he was left with his thoughts. Those who knew him, knew he brooded extremely well. So, he was on the front porch, smoking and brooding thinking. What the brooding came down to was the fact that he needed to be two people at once if he was going to be able to satisfy the two people he loved. Or was it three people? Did Vlad count as two people when Alucard was waiting for him in 1947? When it came down to it, Nadia gave him something Vlad couldn't - her very human self. Not "normal" perhaps, but human and smart and funny and beautiful and occasionally nicely ruthless and whether it spoke good or ill of him, he thrived when he was with her and when he could take care of her. The dream of a future in which they were together and had found a way to balance both their lives enough to have Bailey warmed him. At the same time, there was Vlad. And Alucard. To have a future with Nadia in which that happened, was to abandon Alucard and Hellsing in the past and Vlad in this present. Vlad had more than fifty more years of memories of the two of them together, and without those? How could he leave Alucard with nothing? He had nothing. Everything he was belonged to Hellsing. Walter usually respected Arthur and he believed in Hellsing's mission with all his heart, but his treatment of Alucard was that of an owner. After a fashion, he reconciled that as Alucard's prison term for past crimes. If he figured it properly, Vlad had served more than a hundred year sentence and now he was free. So, Nadia, whom he loved in all her human frailty and destiny-touched madness and compassion and humor and beauty. And Alucard, whom he loved in all his inhuman madness and bloodthirstiness and intelligence and humor and beauty. And Vlad, whom he loved for all the same reasons and who was free and who had waited seven years to steal just a little more time with him. He wanted to be Bailey's father and Alucard's companion during his servitude and Vlad's companion in a long and empty freedom. And somewhere he'd chosen at least two of those things, hadn't/wouldn't he? Bailey existed, so he chose Nadia. Vlad remembered half a century of the two of them together, so he'd chosen Alucard and Hellsing. If he'd chosen two things, why couldn't he figure out a third? And how did the first two choices work? The same way he'd been Brian Slade? Add that in. Somewhere, he was a 70s glam pop star. And somewhere he'd died in the Blitz. And somewhere he'd burned out and died when his metabolism had eaten him alive? And somewhere else he'd probably been killed by a vampire in his first foray into the world of vampire hunting. He sensed an answer in there. Maybe he didn't need to sit back and say, "Somewhere I'm Bailey's father." Maybe he needed to make it happen.... By the same token, maybe he didn't need to feel so helpless about Alucard and Vlad. Maybe... Maybe he didn't have to leave his lover alone in the past or the future.... [ooc: Establishy, but it's a public place.]

Walter sat with his feet dangling out his bedroom window and smoked cigarette after cigarette. He entertained and discarded a variety of ideas: Run off with Vlad. Run off with Nadia. Go home and tell Arthur he'd send pictures of him in bed with Alucard in female form to the Queen if he tried to send him away again. Try to find Fandom and find the Nadia he'd left and apologize. Become an Iscariot. Buy himself a chastity belt and throw away the key. His talk with Vlad had... not gone well or would not have gone well once it was done being played out. The vampire was hurt, insulted, and angry. And it had been such a good weekend otherwise. He could have backed out. Told Nadia that he wasn't going to do it. That he'd chosen Vlad over her. But he really couldn't. It would have been a lie. So now he was on the outs with Vlad, and he didn't want Nadia to think he was going to her just because of that. So... hang out the window and smoke. Nothing new there.

After a handwaved drive into New Orleans and Vlad's kindly "convincing" the concierge that there was no problem with finding the pair a cottage, the two had been comfortably ensconced in their quarters for the weekend. The rest of the night's activities might be left to the imagination. When breakfast was delivered, Walter forced himself out of bed long enough to fetch the tray and set it on the table on the far side of the bed from Vlad. He got back into bed with his lover and sipped at the coffee that had come with the breakfast. "Can we make a habit of this?" [ooc: NFB as out of town.]

Walter leaned against his bedroom door after he was certain that he was not going to have to deal with any further mother henning from any of his friends. 

He could sleep... 

Once the earth stopped rotating on its axis quite so offensively. 

So... sleep was out for a while. 

Which left what? Reading? Not bloody likely. Staring at the ceiling? Nope. 

He needed to tell Alucard about this. The one from his time. 

No time like the present. 

It took four tries to punch the number in correctly, but eventually he heard the crack and hiss of an extremely long distance connection and then the phone was ringing.

Walter moved around his room methodically unpacking his suitcases. He stacked pictures under the corkboard that conveniently happened to be over one of the two desks in the room. They'd go up soon enough. Clothes were shaken out, ironed as needed, and hung up. "You aren't going to need a heating pad here for a while," he murmured to Pup, who was following him around the room as though Walter had bacon in his pocket. If Pup ate anything like bacon. Which reminded him - he was going to need to find a way to feed his pet that didn't involve opening a vein every day or two. That got a bit messy. Work was always something to keep his mind occupied. Unfortunately he worked fast, which meant that soon enough, he was out of ways to keep his mind on other things. Scooping up Pup, he opened the window and sat on the sill with the hellpuppy cradled in his arms while he looked out at the lush green surroundings. This was not England. He was 60 years and 4,000 miles separated from home and Alucard. And Pippi, Pip, and Nadia were here. Nadia.... One of the pictures in the stack to be put up on the corkboard was of a very, very dirty little girl hugging Nadia. Several others were of Nadia alone or with their friends. Many more were of Alucard. He'd had two years at home with Alucard. Time in which to clear up their "misunderstandings." Time in which to grow much closer and use the word "love" without question. And it had hurt terribly when Arthur had separated them again to send Walter to this school. He certainly didn't want to throw things to the wind within moments of arriving in a new place. But he hadn't lied when he told Nadia he loved her years ago in Fandom. He hadn't even wanted to tell her he loved her when they both knew that she wouldn't be the only one in his heart. But done was done, and after those words were said, he didn't want to undo it. And in two years in his own time and place, he still loved her. So what the hell was he supposed to do? It had hurt them both when he'd left Fandom and all he could ever do was hurt her by leaving because he had to go home to Hellsing and to Alucard. But Bailey had to have her parents. Walter silently cursed Arthur and lit a cigarette. If his employer had known Nadia was here and hoped she would come between him and Alucard, he was going to hire the man the most diseased whore in London. Walter sat and thought and smoked until the familiar sounds of a guitar drifted up to him. Two years weren't enough time to change- it hadn't been two years for her. Of course she hadn't changed, it had only been a month. He muttered a curse and set Pup down. All he knew for the moment was that he was stuck here for the next year or two, and his friends were here and running away wasn't going to help him at all. Time to go see Nadia. [ooc: Establishy. Not open for interaction because he's not there now.]

From this point forward, this journal will be used for <lj user="milieux_ecole">. All FH related posts will remain viewable and public, of course, but unless you want to watch Walter somewhere else, now would be the time to remove him from your flists. 

Thanks. It's been fun.

If you need to get in touch with me, I'm in AIM at walterdornez or gTalk walter.todesengel. That's also my gmail address. You can also leave messages here. Posts are screened in case you need me for admin-y stuff.
I'm unavailable to take your call at the moment. Please leave a message and I'll return your call at my earliest convenience. Thank you.

Walter had his suitcases, Pup in a dog carrier, and was as ready as he was going to get for a one-way trip back to 1945. He'd left all of his various anachronistic doodads back in the room, and the roomies were welcome to computer, phone, CDs, CD player, etc. Everything else was packed and ready to go. 

<small>[ooc: Post is public. Handwave Walter having sent an email if you want. After this post, he's gone. Thanks very much, I've had a wonderful time playing him here. SP is goodness.]

Walter had cleared off his bed, found a box for Nadia, and made a general announcement to the room's pets that there would be violence and blood if anyone dared harm her. 

The degu was unimpressed. He wasn't sure what Furrball or Cuddles thought of the declaration. 

He settled in for the night, checking Nadia often for some sign that she was changing back, like less fur, or turning into a wee nude Nadia in the box or something. 

No such luck. 

He put his glasses aside on the bedside table and looked down at Nadia again. "Good night...." He looked around shiftily before scooping the degu out of the box. 

It worked on the frog.... 

He gave the degu a kiss and waited. When it stayed stubbornly a degu, Walter put it back in the box. "Good night, Nadia."

Walter wasn't pacing. Much. He was watching the doors, looking at the clock, and looking out the window quite a bit, though. After tonight's radio, he was waiting for Nadia to come back and explain what she'd been talking about. [ooc: Open for Steerpike or roomies.]

Walter was going through his things trying to determine what he could take with him. CD player? No. Which left the CDs right out as well. Laptop? Yeah, right. Phone? Ditto. 

Clothes. Yes. Non-electronics. Yes. Books? Much more problematic. He decided to leave anything with a copyright after 1950. Yes, that was a five year cheat. It still included almost all of his books anyway. 

Digital camera.... It was with great regret that he put that in the "can't take" pile. 

<small>[ooc: Open.]

This might be one of Walter's last chances to call Alfred, since there wasn't going to be much chance of cross-temporal phone calls in 1945. 

And he was going to miss the old bastard. 

Even more than he already did. 

He listened to the tone and mentally urged his mentor to pick up.

Walter trudged back up from the causeway and slipped as quietly as he could into 502/4/6, leaving his bag unopened by the door and scooping Pup up before he could yap and wake his roommates. Which just left him with a hellpuppy frantically sniffing his face and shirt for the source of the Daddy smell. Really, those sixty-year jaunts were tiring, but at least this time he was returning in one piece. Walter flopped down on the bed, shoes still on, and promptly fell asleep.
 

Walter got out of the car and looked up at the imposing building that housed the Hellsing Organization. This had been home to him for four years and then he'd gone to Fandom. It was hard to believe that it was nine whole months since he'd last gone home.

Being called on the carpet for his attendance and grades was not the way he'd wanted to go home.

It felt like being put in his place as a servant rather than some odd sort of member of the family.

Or he could just be feeling jetlagged, timelagged, whatever-lagged.

He set his shoulders, gave directions to the driver to have his bag taken to his room, and went inside. The sooner he got this part over with, the better. 

 

Arthur had fully intended to be on scene to meet Hellsing's young protege. He had even half made up his mind to be on the airplane that would take Walter back to 1945.

But,then something had come up. A rather large something that had taken twodays of no sleep and a large measure of blind, stupid luck to fix.

Now, Hellsing's chief sat at his desk. Arthur was dressed impeccably, the lines of his suit flawless, his collar and cuffs crisp, his cufflinks gleaming. But, the lines of his face were drawn, weary, and grim.

Restless, he toyed with a fountain pen, twirling it in his fingers. 

 

Three-quarters of a year gone and little had changed. As he walked through the house and upstairs to Arthur's office, he checked for details - the state of the chandelier, dust on the crown molding, the way the paintings were being kept up.

He had a few complaints, but at least the manor wouldn't embarrass Arthur. He'd have a few words with the staff before he had to leave again to correct those small matters.

Those thoughts kept him occupied on the walk to Arthur's office, but inevitably, he ended up out of walk, standing at his master's door.

With a last sigh, he knocked on the door and opened it enough to slip inside, waiting silently for Arthur to acknowledge his arrival. 

 

Growing up with a vampire in the house makes one's peripheral vision very keen, indeed. Walter was stealthy, inhumanly so. But, he was no Alucard.

Arthur allowed himself a smile and stood to greet Walter.

"Welcome back, my boy." 

 

Walter nodded to Arthur and approached the man's desk. "Thank you, sir."

This room could use cleanup. He wondered if Arthur permitted anyone in here while Walter was gone, or if this was just the remnants of a day's researching. With Arthur, Walter wasn't sure he could guess. 

 

At this moment, Arthur's office best resembled an archaeological dig.

The first, bottom layer was the detritus of Arthur's day to day life; dirty plates, empty bottles, well-loved blue magazines.

On top of that were documents, memos, folders, and all the other odds and ends that came with running Hellsing and staying on top of wartime developments.

The topmost layer was, indeed, the remnants of researching. And, of an experiment. An experiment which was the reason that Arthur had been awake for the past forty eight hours. Papers littered his desk, scribbled with a strange mix of arcane symbols and scientific equations. And, spatters of dried blood.

Arthur gestured towards the chair before his desk.

"Come in, Walter. Please, sit." 

 

Arthur looked tired and there was blood on his desk; this was anything but promising.

And where was Alucard? There'd been no sense of him on Walter's walk to the office.

Wordlessly, he cleared a few papers off the chair, squaring them in a stack before setting them atop another stack on the floor and taking a seat. Small talk didn't seem appropriate to the moment. 

 

Arthur Hellsing was a lush and a womanizer. He was also a practised politician and a canny strategist.

He knew how to be evasive, how to use jargon, how to talk for half an hour and have said nothing at all.

He also knew when to cut to the chase. He rested his elbows on the desk and leaned forward, fixing his gaze on his young butler's face.

"What's happened, Walter?" 

 

Walter had known this was coming and had prepared himself for it during his long trip across the Atlantic and six decades.

The hard part was that he didn't have a good reason. Or at least not one that sounded right anywhere but in his head.

"I can't really say, sir. I suppose the classes aren't keeping my attention, and I'd rather be training than doing classwork." 

 

Arthur sighed and sat back in his chair.

"You resented my forcing the matter when it came to sending and keeping you at school, didn't you, Walter?" 

 Well, since Arthur asked the question point blank, Walter wasn't about to lie to him. "Yes, I did." 
 

Arthur nodded. He'd more then suspected as much.

"I am not an easy man to work for. The duties you perform for Hellsing are not easy. It was with this in mind that I sent you away to school. However..."

Arthur trailed off then leaned forward again.

"I value you, Walter," he continued, "As more than a simple employee. And, I think...I hope that you know this." 

 

Walter's feelings on whether that was true or not had swung from he doesn't give a damn as long as the manor's in shape and the enemies are dead to he's trying to protect me and back again more than once.

But he didn't think Arthur would flat out lie to his face, so he nodded to acknowledge the man's words.

Much of his problem was that he liked Fandom, and more than liked a few people there. But it wasn't home, and it wasn't 

 

Arthur's features softened for the barest instant. He cleared his throat

"Good. That puts my mind at ease. And, so I hope you will understand that I don't wish there to be resentments between us, Walter."

Arthur took a deep breath and cleared his throat.

"So, the choice I am about to give you is yours to make. Completely. Do you understand that, Walter?" 

 

Walter was grateful for the additional training he'd had with Alfred, because it took it all to keep his expression under control at Arthur's question.

Was he really going to give Walter the choice he thought he was? Only one way to find out.

"Yes, sir. I understand." 

 

Arthur nodded.

"Very well."

He paused a moment to collect his thoughts, then began.

"You know why I have called you here. And, now, so do I. I know I need not reiterate these things. So, in light of what has come to pass..."

Arthur paused and leaned forward, fixing his gaze on Walter's face.

"Will you go back to school and continue on in your classes, or will you return to Hellsing and take up your posts as butler and Angel of Death?" 

 

Yes! No. Maybe.

Shit.

"May I give you my decision before I leave, sir? I would have to return for my belongings if nothing else." 

 

Arthur nodded.

"Of course you may, Walter. Take as long as you need to decide. I'll arrange it with your school." 

 "Thank you." Walter found old roles easy to slip back into. "If there's nothing else, sir, you look as though you could use some rest." 
 

Arthur allowed himself another smile and pinched the bridge of his nose.

"As indeed I could. Consider yourself at liberty for the rest of the day, Walter. I'll retire shortly." 

 

Walter rose with a nod for Arthur and looked around the office. He needed to get in here while Arthur was resting - possibly with a shovel.

Before he left, though, a question for Hellsing's master. "Sir? Is Alucard away on a mission?"  

 

Arthur shook his head and cast his gaze down at the blood-speckled papers before him. He began to gather them.

"No, Alucard is not on a mission. Alucard is resting." 

 

Resting? Arthur's behavior put together with that bit of information didn't make Walter feel particularly comfortable.

"As you should be, sir."

He pulled the door open to leave, intending to go to Alucard's chamber to look in on the vampire. 

 

Arthur could make an educated guess as to where Walter's next stop would be. He came close to calling Walter back, sending him out on some pretext, some errand.

But, that was beneath them both, really.

Besides, whether or not Walter chose to stay at school or to return to Hellsing, he and Alucard would be partnered again. Hellsing's elite trashmen.

Arthur was not foolish enough to waste energy in putting off the inevitable. He would wait and watch and pick his battles.

He was, after all, a Hellsing. 

 

From Arthur's room, Walter headed downstairs. He stopped along the way to catch up with a few staff members. It's easier when you're a teenager telling adults what to do, if they know you well enough to know you're actually competent to be giving the orders.

After finding out who had left because she was pregnant, who had quit because she couldn't stand Alucard any longer, and who the new girl taking care of the East Wing was, Walter headed deeper into Hellsing. Down stairs that most staff never descended, deeper into the basement where even fewer went, and down the long hall that heard few footsteps that were not his or Arthur's.

At the end of the hallway, he stopped before knocking gently on the door and pushing it open. Alucard would know who was there, had no doubt heard him well before he reached the door. 

 

As Walter pushed the door open, he would be able to see Alucard's room with its Spartan furnishings. A simple bed. A wooden table and next to it, a high-backed chair.

Everything except Hellsing's vampire and his coffin.

On the table, a goblet had been turned over, and blood dripped over its edge and onto the floor in a slow, steady patter. 

 

Walter frowned and crossed to right the glass, looking around for some sign of Alucard. It couldn't have been that long since Alucard was there if the blood was still dripping.

He wasn't expecting a response, but still.... "Alucard?" 

 

Alucard was far away, down at the end of the corridor.

He'd been searching for something, but had forgotten what. When he'd paused, leaned against a wall and tried to remember, he'd begun to hear a soft noise.

It was low and steady, very quick and very familiar.

With an effort, Alucard turned and began to walk back towards that noise, his mind now entirely focused on recalling what it was and finding it. 

 

Nothing. He wasn't too surprised. If Alucard's coffin wasn't here, Walter didn't expect to find Alucard.

The only thing that made no sense was the glass....

He didn't expect to find the vampire hiding under the bed, either, and didn't look.

Resting... where would Alucard be resting if he and his coffin were not here? Given Arthur's state, his next stop as he turned to leave the chamber would be the labs. 

 

Alucard kept moving towards the noise. Sometimes he could manage on his own, and sometimes he leaned heavily against the wall, using it to support himself as he walked.

The noise grew louder with his every step, but he still could not remember. The answer flashed before his mind then disappeared before hie could grasp it. It danced on the tip of his tongue, then fluttered away before he could speak.

Alucard gave a frustrated growl and pushed forward. 

 

Walter left the room and was just pulling the door closed behind himself when movement down the poorly-lit hall caught his eye.

Someone injured? A trap? A wayward servant lucky he was encountering Walter and not Alucard?

He stepped away from the wall and toward the movement. 

 

Alucard's eyes widened, then narrowed.

There was some...one. Someone at moving down the hall. They were coming closer, and as they moved, the nature of the noise changed.

It grew louder, swifter, becoming a buzz, a hum that shivered over Alucard's brain and down his spine to the very tips of his fingers.

What is that? I know it...I know...

He pressed onward, his steps growing steadier as he went. 

 

Alucard.

The white hair that drifted around Alucard's shoulders was an indicator of the vampire's condition, and Walter made haste to close the distance between them.

Resting. Right.

"Alucard...." 

 

Alucard...

The noise grew louder and faster, louder and faster...And...yes...

A cold London night. Winter drizzle and fog coming in from the Thames. The dank smell of a back alley.

A flash of silver and his hand lay in the gutter. And, throughout it all, in the back ground... That noise.

A deluge of memories came back to him all at once, swirling and churning through the courses of his mind. All to be channeled and distilled into a single, hushed word.

"Angel...?" 

 

He looked so lost, it twisted Walter's stomach into a knot.

What had happened?

He nodded and drew closer, holding out a hand to Alucard.

"It's me. And you look like you should be resting the way Arthur said you were." 

 

Alucard stared at Walter's outstretched hand for a moment. Then he closed the distance between them and rested his own hand on top of it.

It was an old fashioned gesture, a remnant of some ancient court's etiquette.

As Alucard felt the heat from Walter's skin soak into his palm, his confused expression relaxed into comprehension.

"Ah. It was your heartbeat." 

 "What was?" Walter asked as he took Alucard's hand to hook it through his arm and start walking the vampire back toward his room. 
 "The sound," replied Alucard as he walked alongside Walter, "I was following it when we found each other." 
 Walter sighed and pulled Alucard's door open for him. "What's happened to you, Alucard? And where is your coffin?" 
 

As his door opened and he stepped through, the scent of the spilled blood hit Alucard like a physical blow.

A shudder ran the length of his long body and he found his gaze riveted to the small table with its tipped over glass and icy champagne bucket.

"Another experiment," he said, his voice low, almost a growl, "And, Arthur has had my coffin removed for the time being." 

 

Separating Alucard from his coffin? What was Arthur thinking?

And Alucard's reaction was easy enough to read. It was just Walter's luck that there wasn't more blood in the ice bucket.

"Then let me get you to bed, and I'll go fetch you some more blood."

It struck him then that there was no one else who would be with Alucard through times like these. Arthur wouldn't tend to him, the soldiers were right out, and there wasn't a servant in the building who would do it.

Dammit.

"I'll keep you company when I get back if you'd like." 

 

Yes, he was a walking shambles. But, there was still enough of Alucard's essential personality left that he would recoil from anything he might perceive as pity.

"Do as you wish, Angel." 

 

Walter kept his expression neutral even if he was rolling his eyes internally.

"I wish," he said firmly, steering Alucard to the bed. "After reporting to Arthur, this is the first place I came." 

 

For that, Alucard had no reply.

He simply allowed himself to be steered towards the bed. 

 

Walter managed to get Alucard to the bed and settled into place before collecting the ice bucket and reluctantly leaving the vampire to go upstairs.

Ordinarily, he'd stop to talk with servants and soldiers as he had on his way down to Alucard's room, but Alucard was waiting for him, and obviously needed what Walter was fetching.

He paused long enough in the medical wing to give his regards to Dr. Trevalion, collected several bottles of blood, and headed back downstairs, his fast walk more like a run for most people. 

 

Alucard remained on the bed, eyes shut as he tried to sort his memories and regain some sort of equilibrium before Walter returned.

The vampire found himself caught between being elated at seeing Walter once more and being angry that Walter should see him in his current condition. 

 

Sleeping? Walter rather doubted it, but if Alucard was sleeping, that was probably to the good.

He set the bucket on the table and pulled out one of the bottles. He used his handkerchief to wipe off Alucard's glass and refilled it before crossing to sit on the edge of the bed and wait for Alucard to open his eyes.

 

Alucard lay still and listened to Walter's moving about his room. He followed the other man's sounds from the door, to the table, to his bed.

The vampire remained as he was, taking in Walter's breathing and his heart beat. He could feel the ghost of Walter's body heat as he sat down.

After a time, Alucard opened his eyes.

"AB negative?" he asked with a slight smile. 

 

"Of course," Walter said, holding out the glass. "Would I forget your favorite?"

It was almost a reversal of their last time together. This time he was whole and Alucard was in need of care.

He also knew how much they both loathed needing help. They weren't all that different in many ways.

 

"They've been giving me O," replied Alucard, annoyed.

The look he gave the glass as he reached out to take it from Walter was similar to the look that someone who'd been eating hospital food for the past month would give his first real meal.

"Thank you, Angel," he said as his fingers closed around the goblet. 

 

"That's stupid of them," Walter said, rolling his eyes. "O is more versatile for medical use than your preferred."

He'd have to have words with whomever had been bringing Alucard his meals.

Or... he could just return to doing it himself. It was a choice. 

 "That was the idea, I believe," replied Alucard, "Similar to how unwell humans are fed simple foods." 
 

That would almost make sense - if you applied human standards to someone who very much was not human. "Do you think it actually makes a difference?" 

 

"No. As I will inform Arthur and Dr. Trevelian the next time they see me."

Alucard took the glass from Walter's hand then and brought it to his lips for a long drink. 

 

"Ah." No doubt people could or would watch Alucard drink and tell themselves it was wine or tomato juice. Or they'd just look away. Walter didn't bother. It was what sustained his... whatever it was that Alucard was to him.

"May I bring you anything else?" 

 

Alucard finished the last of the blood in his glass and shook his head.

"No. Thank you."

He sat silently for a moment, turning the goblet's stem between his long fingers.

"Are you well?"

The time between letters and telephone calls had been long, after all. 

 

Walter felt a pang of guilt and watched Alucard's fingers rather than his face for a moment. "Yes. It's been a while since there were any good fights to be had at school."

This was so damned awkward. He finally stood up to retrieve the bottle from the table to refill Alucard's glass. At least it gave him something to do. 

 

Alucard sighed as he watched Walter stand and move over to the table.

"You still can't sit still for five minutes, I see," he said, his tone amused. 

 

"Maybe that's why I haven't been going to classes," Walter replied, taking the glass from Alucard and emptying the bottle into it. 

 

Alucard watched him pour, fixated equally on the flowing read liquid and on the movement of Walter's fingers as they held the bottle and the glass.

He had other memories of those fingers that, in this state, were difficult to put aside.

"Is it why?" 

 

"Some, I suppose." Although he'd been able to rein in his restlessness better in prior semesters.

Walter held out the glass for Alucard to take from him. "And even though I like it there, and I've made some friends I don't want to give up, I have to think that my loyalties lie here. Not just when it's convenient." 

 

"I don't believe that your loyalty to Hellsing has ever been called into question, Walter," replied Alucard as the reached to take the glass, slipping his fingers around the stem, just beneath Walter's hand. 

 

"Nobody has to do it for me." Walter held on to the glass for a moment before releasing it into Alucard's grasp.

"It's not right. No one else gets to leave the war behind entirely and just live in another decade until everything blows over." 

 

Alucard held his glass, but did not drink.

"Angel..." he began and waited until Walter's gaze met his, "You have a strong sense of duty. I have always respected it, but...I don't think I can advise you in this matter...Not impartially, at any rate." 

 Walter held Alucard's gaze and nodded. "I'm to tell Arthur before I leave whether I'm returning to Fandom to collect my things or to continue my classes." 
 

Alucard was worn and weary with the experiment. And so, he lacked some of the defenses necessary to be his usual, inscrutable self.

"That is..." he began and broke off to take a drink when he realised he did not know how to continue. 

 "'That is good'? or 'That is unfortunate'?" Walter asked. It did make a difference. He wasn't sure if it should, but it did. 
 

Damn Arthur for choosing now for to put him through this particular experiment. One that had loosened his memory, calling forth 500 years worth of failures, of mistakes.

One that almost had him believing that he was on the cusp of creating yet another regret.

Alucard took a moment to force them away and to remind himself that while he had been many things, a coward had never been one of them.

I can love, he reminded himself, I can, and I do.

"Do you remember the last time we were together, Angel?" he asked, "You told me that you'd thought you were going to die? And, that you had wanted to see me?" 

 

Walter nodded. He remembered all of that discussion. "I remember, Alucard."

He rather hoped he could see where this was going. 

 

"During the experiments...after them...you're who I want to see." 

 

Neither Nadia nor Alucard would appreciate the thoughts in Walter's head at that moment. Thus he'd never verbalize them to either, ever.

But Alucard's words had their effect and he nodded. "I'm glad that I'm here now." 

 

Alucard took in Walter's words, but he also took in the physical distance that Walter maintained between them.

It stung.

He nodded once and leaned over to set his glass on the floor beside the bed, suddenly not so thirsty any longer. 

 

"You look tired." Alucard looked more than tired, he looked nearly done in.

"I could stay here, if you'd like," he offered. "While you rest." He could use some rest himself. 

 "I would like it if you stayed to rest with me," replied Alucard, "I would like it very much. But, I also want to know...why it is you are offering to." 
 "Because I want to." Walter shifted closer to him. "Why did you sleep next to me on the way back from Poland?" 
 

"Because I wanted to," replied Alucard, sitting up, "And, I wanted to because I had missed you. Very much." 

 

"And I have missed you, Alucard." It was much simpler not to miss him when he could put it away where so many other feelings could be put away.

Or perhaps, more accurately, it was easier not to feel it.

"So, I want to stay here. We can both rest. It's been a long trip." 

 "Are you certain, Angel? I don't think I can change into a wolf, this time." 
 

"Then don't." Walter picked up the glass and held it out for Alucard again. "I still want to stay."

Which was starting to mean something a bit different than it had earlier. 

 

Alucard looked at the glass, then back up at Walter.

"Later," he said, leaning back once more. 

 "As you wish." Walter set the glass down again. "Do you want me to come back later as well? Or shall I stay?" 
 

"I want you to stay," replied Alucard, not taking his eyes from Walter, "But, where will you rest?" 

 

Other times in this bed.... Walter put the thought aside.

"I can take the chair or join you in the bed, as you prefer."

 

The corner of Alucard's mouth twitched.

"And, if I asked you to curl up on the table top?" 

 "You want your table broken?" Walter asked, delivering the question with a straight face. "Because I can do that if you'd like." 
 

"I doubt it," replied Alucard, his face equally dead-pan, "You're still skinny as a rail."

He leaned back, a definite smirk on his face.

"Unless you meant you'd destroy it in a fit of pique. Which would mean you're still a damned brat. And skinny as a rail." 

 

"I've moved on from destroying furniture out of pique." That's what the island junkyard was for. "And I'm not skinny as a rail. I'm wiry."

His lips twitched. "So, chair, bed, or table? Or will you have me curl up on your stone floor?" 

 

Alucard chuckled.

"If you had really wanted the chair, you'd be in it, already," replied Alucard, "So quit preveracating and come join me, Angel." 

 

"I didn't say I wanted the chair." Walter toed off his shoes and went around to the other side of the bed to lie down.

"And you'll actually rest?" 

 "I will rest." 
 "And so shall I." There was room for both of them on the bed, but Walter lay close enough that Alucard could rest against him if he chose. "A sixty year jaunt can be a bit tiring." 
 "So can reliving 500 odd years in just under an hour..." 
 Walter propped his head up on a hand to watch Alucard. "Then we can tell each other about it after we've both rested." 
 

Alucard gave a soft chuckle, but he turned to face Walter.

"I'm not so sure it's a story you would like to hear. You can make so many mistakes in five hundred years..."

Slowly, he reached out to touch his fingertips to Walter's cheek.

"Have I loved you well, Angel?" he asked, "Did I get that right, at least?" 

 Walter closed his eyes. To see Alucard like this was... disturbing, at best. Opening them again, he nodded. "I think I didn't appreciate it properly." 
 

"Do you think that?"

Alucard moved his hand from Walter's cheek and let his arm drape over Walter's body.

"I'm not the easiest creature to love," he said, a smile hovering over his lips, "I know. So, don't let it bother you, too much." 

 Walter shook his head. "Not true." And God knows his life would be so much simpler if it were. "I find you impossible not to love." 
 

Alucard leaned forward and pressed his lips to Walter's forehead.

"I love you, too, Angel."

He settled back down against the pillow and closed his eyes to feel Walter's warm breath against his skin.

"I know that it's only because Arthur summoned you," he said, "But, I'm glad you're here." 

 Walter also closed his eyes and put aside all of the other worries he'd have to deal with after resting - deciding whether to return to school to study or to pack, dealing with his relationships, and dealing with his relationships. One way or another, things were changing.

That could wait. Right now, he could focus on Alucard's words and the familiar/strange feeling of being in bed with him. It had been a very long time.

And for that moment, regardless of any problems to come, he was fully truthful in saying, "I'm glad I'm here, too."

Brown Rice Gratin 2 cups broccoli florets 3 cups cooked brown rice 1 cup (8 oz.) shredded Swiss or Jarlsberg cheese (although I always use at least twice that and prefer Jarlsberg) 3/4 cup regular-strength chicken broth (you can substitute vegetable broth for a vegetarian, but not vegan, friendly recipe) 1/2 cup sour cream 1/2 cup chopped green onion 1/4 cup minced fresh cilantro 2 tablespoons Dijon mustard 1/4 teaspoon pepper 1/4 cup fine dry bread crumbs mixed with 2 teaspoons melted butter or margerine In a wok or 4- to 5-quart pan, place broccoli on a rack above 1 inch of boiling water. Cover and steam until florets are just tender when pierced, about 9 minutes. In a large bowl, mix broccoli, rice, cheese, broth, sour cream, onion, cilantro, mustard, and pepper. Spread evenly in a 9- by 13-inch oval or rectangular casserole. Sprinkle with bread crumbs. Bake in a 350 degree oven until casserole is hot in center and crumbs are browned, 15 to 20 minutes.
